awd_titl_txt: Investigating Geobiological Feedbacks During the Evolution of Acidophilic  Microorganisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial communities drive global biogeochemical cycles and link critical ecosystem processes influencing plant, animal, and environmental health. Consequently, a central goal in the geosciences is to develop new understanding of the interactions between the geosphere and the biosphere that have influenced the evolution of geochemical cycles and the diversification of life. Perhaps the most prominent of such interactions involves the emergence of oxygenic phototrophs and the product of their metabolic activity, oxygen (O2). Accumulating evidence indicates that the introduction of oxygen to an anaerobic biosphere had a profound influence on geochemical cycles and the functional diversification of microbial life. While the fingerprint of oxygen on the cycling of elements in the geosphere and biosphere over geological time is increasingly coming into focus, key questions remain on the nature of the dynamic feedbacks between the coupled evolution of the geosphere and the biosphere and on the timescales over which key events took place. New data suggests that the co-evolution of organisms that characteristically inhabit acidic hot springs (thermoacidophiles) and the acidic nature of the hot spring habitats themselves was likely driven by a series of geobiological feedbacks that have taken place over the past one billion years, near to the time when atmospheric oxygen is thought have reached near present-day levels. These unique low complexity acidic ecosystems provide an opportunity to test and further develop integrated concepts in the geosciences, including identifying the dynamics between the coupled evolution of geochemical habitats and the metabolic potential of their microbial inhabitants. The new understanding and analytical tools that are developed from the study of low complexity acidic ecosystems will be applicable to more complex ecosystems and processes, including those that have direct bearing on the geobiological feedbacks that sustain plant, animal, and environmental health. Results from these studies will be disseminated by students, postdocs, and the senior scientists supported by the project through presentations at national and international conferences and through submission of journal articles, thereby boosting professional development. 

There is widespread recognition of the role of feedbacks between biological and geological processes in the co-evolution of environmental landscapes and the biodiversity they support. However, far less is known of the nature of these feedbacks and the time scales over which they occur, especially from the biological perspective. This is due, in part, to the complexity of most contemporary ecosystems and the difficulty this presents in deconvoluting the geobiological interactions that have shaped these habitats and their inhabitants. This knowledge gap prevents the development of a more complete understanding of the generation of biological diversity, both today and in the geological past, and perhaps more importantly, limits our ability to link geochemical and biological biomarkers in the rock record. New data suggests that the evolution of thermoacidophilic microorganisms and the largescale generation of acidic habitats was likely driven by a series of geobiological feedbacks that have taken place over the past one billion years. More specifically, data indicates that at least two divergent archaeal lineages converged evolutionarily upon similar, oxygen-dependent metabolic strategies to survive acid conditions, and we have hypothesized that, in doing so, they have constructed highly acidic ecological niches. In this work we will address this hypothesis by combining field- and laboratory-based analyses aimed at defining constraints on the kinetics of abiotic and biotic sulfur oxidation, the physiology of thermoacidophiles, and the coupled evolution of acidic habitats and their thermoacidophilic inhabitants. Specifically, we will apply state of the art molecular, physiological, evolutionary, geochemical, and modeling approaches to test our primary hypothesis that taxonomic and functional diversity of microorganisms in acidic hot spring environments evolved in concert with the oxygen-dependent, biologically induced acidification of those environments. In this work, we will evaluate the influence of oxygen on (i) the kinetics of sulfur oxidation over a pH and temperature continuum, (ii) the adaptations that facilitate habitation along this continuum and, (iii) the co-evolution of these lineages and their acidic habitats. Completion of this project will culminate in a more complete understanding of how interactions between microorganisms and their environment can lead to biological diversification and geological change, using thermoacidophiles and their acidic hot spring habitats as a model. New understanding and bioinformatics tools that we develop from the study of these low complexity ecosystems will be applicable to more complex ecosystems and processes. Results will be disseminated by students, postdocs, and the PI through presentations at national and international conferences and through submission of journal articles, thereby boosting professional development. Through this work, we will continue to recruit and offer research opportunities to motivated undergraduate and graduate students, particularly underrepresented Native Americans. To achieve this goal, we will continue the partnership that has been forged with Salish Kootenai College to attract undergraduates to complete a six-week summer research internship at Montana State University, with the goal of recruiting students from this demographic to seek an advanced degree in a STEM discipline.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All forms of life interact with their environment to obtain energy and nutrients and in doing so modify thier environment. Given that this is true for all forms of life today, parsimony would suggest this to be true for life from its very beginnings >3.8 billion years ago to the present, with the implication being that our planet and its biosphere have co-evolved over this period of time.  What is not known are the mode and tempo of such interactions. This presents a barrier in understanding how biodiversity is generated and maintained and how environmental landscapes evolve. 

 

High temperature hot springs have extreme conditions that limit microbial diversity and that result in communities that are comprised of a comparatively small number of populations.  Further, the extreme conditions in hot springs exclude certain metabolic groups, including organisms that conduct photosynthesis (generate energy from light). Microorganisms that inhabit high temperature springs are therefore more closely tied to their environment since they are dependent on chemical energy available in those habitats to support their metabolism. Together, these features of hot springs – extreme geochemical conditions, reduced community complexity, and the presence of organisms dependent on chemical energy - make them model systems for understanding ecological and evolutionary processes. What is learned from these simplified yet natural model systems can then be applied to other less extreme environments, where such relationships may be more nuanced and less easy to decipher.

 

The Yellowstone Hydrothermal System covers an expanse of ~10,000 square miles and manifests at the surface as >10,000 hot springs, fumaroles, geysers, and mudpots that dot the landscape. Hot springs tend to be either circumneutral to alkaline pH (pH >7) or acid pH (pH <4), with very few springs intermediate to these groups. Further, acidic springs tend to be enriched in sulfur compounds as well as Archaea. A leading model for hot spring acidification invokes boiling of fluids in the subsurface resulting in the separation of volcanic gases from liquids, with the latter emerging at the surface as hot springs or geysers with pH >7. Oxidation of volcanic gases containing hydrogen sulfide (H2S, smells like rotten eggs) ultimately generates sulfuric acid that leads to the acidification of springs (pH <4).

 

The primary goal of this project was to evaluate the role of biological activity in the acidification of hot springs and to determine the extent to which acidification promoted taxonomic and functional diversification of microbial lineages. Through application of phylogenetic/evolutionary tools in concert with genomic data recovered from hot springs, we showed that the organisms that are primarily responsible for the development of acidity in hot springs are oxygen (O2)-dependent, sulfur oxidizing thermoacidophilic Archaea within the order Sulfolobales. These organisms diversified from their circumneutral pH-adapted ancestors ~600 to 800 million years ago at a time when geochemical models suggest O2 reached present day atmospheric concentrations. As such, the rise of O2 facilitated the diversification of Archaea and facilitated the O2-dependent oxidation of sulfur compounds that lead to the production of sulfuric acid and acidic hot springs. For the past 50 years, scientists attributed the initial oxidation of H2S to generate elemental sulfur to be an abiological process (does not involve biology). However, our work showed that members of the Sulfolobales catalyze H2S oxidation and thereby accelerate the acidification process. Further, we showed that Sulfolobales, which have been implicated primarily as elemental sulfur oxidizing organisms, prefer to grow with sulfide over elemental sulfur, forcing a reconciliation of their role in the acidification process. While sulfide is the preferred electron donor for Sulfolobales, they can oxidize elemental sulfur and physiological characterization of two new isolated members of this order reveal key differences that allow for their co-existence. One strain requires direct contact with the elemental sulfur mineral to oxidize it, while the other does not. This provides new insight into how these metabolically similar organisms can co-exist in hot springs, thereby contributing to a more broad understanding of how behavior can be selectable and contribute to biodiversity.

 

Results of our work were broadly disseminated in seminars, public presentations, field trips to Yellowstone that included members of the public (Yellowstone Forever field courses) and undergraduate students (REU field trip), numerous guest lectures, graduate classroom projects that led to multiple peer reviewed journal publications, and numerous additional peer reviewed publications that formed the basis of a doctoral dissertation. This project provided training opportunities for several undergraduate/graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar, including individuals representing minority demographics. 

 

Collectively, the intellectual merits and broader impacts stemming from this work provide new insight into how microbial diversity is generated in natural systems and its impact on landscape evolution. Project outcomes, including datasets, organisms, and theoretical and experimental approaches, will impact other scientific disciplines that are interested in understanding the co-evolution of the biosphere and the geosphere.
